Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Chlorine-resistant block polymer nanofiltration membranes with added capacity for heavy-metal capture
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is in the development of novel water treatment technologies that can improve access to clean water and reduce the cost of water treatment. The innovation is a drop-in-replacement nanofiltration membrane that is chlorine-resistant, highly permeable, and uniquely customizable. The chlorine resistance allows for the continuous chlorination of the membrane, which can reduce bio-fouling and thereby increase the lifespan of a membrane; this has been a chief innovation target for more than 30 years. The customizability aspect also facilitates capture of lead and other heavy-metals, broadening the reach of nanofiltration membranes to sectors that generate significant amounts of wastewater, such as semiconductor, mining, pulp-and-paper, and colorant industries. These improvements to nanofiltration technology have clear and direct societal and economic impact by facilitating water reuse and offering clean and affordable water solutions. SBIR project funding is enabling the transition of this promising membrane technology from the laboratory setting into the early commercialization stages of a valuable new product.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to improve the commercial viability of novel nanofiltration membranes through the development of more-scalable and tunable synthesis and manufacturing protocols. The technology is based on self-assembling block copolymers with customizable chemical functionalities. Previous methods for the synthesis and casting of the polymers are not ideal, so new protocols are being developed. The changes to polymer and membrane manufacturing methods will be conducted systematically to develop new structure-property-performance relationships that will contribute new knowledge for broader membrane optimization efforts. A more thorough understanding of how polymer chemistry dictates membrane performance will also be cultivated by investing in the customization aspects of the technology. Finally, the performance characteristics of resulting nanofiltration membranes will be rigorously tested with respect to permeability, chlorine-resistance, separations, and heavy metal capture. The overall results will help advance nanofiltration membrane technology into a platform that is highly modular and can address a wider range of separations challenges than is currently possible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a pressing need globally to develop novel technologies that can improve access to clean water and reduce the cost of water treatment.  The specific needs in water treatment vary widely but all factor into cost: higher permeability, better separation efficiency, longer lifespan, lower maintenance, etc. Anfiro?s unique, highly versatile, and optionally customizable nanofiltration (NF) membrane technology is anticipated to meet many aspects of these needs, but only broadly after scale-up and commercialization.

This NSF SBIR Phase I project has had a direct and positive impact on Anfiro?s progress towards commercialization of its novel block copolymer membranes.  Production rates of both the polymer and membrane products have been scaled-up more than fortyfold, maximizing present capacity of both the reactors and roll-to-roll manufacturing lines.  The robustness of the manufacturing process continues to be promising, a fact partially attributable to the kinetic models for polymerization that were developed as part of this project.  The product membrane sheets have remarkably uniform pore-sizes and are effectively defect-free.  Intellectually, this work also reinforced Anfiro?s understanding of how inherent batch-to-batch and day-to-day variables effect membrane performance.  

Overall, this newfound scale of polymer and membrane manufacturing enabled to the assembly of the company?s first 8? long spiral-wound demo elements (a cross-cut example is pictured), a critical milestone for future field-testing. This first generation of the scaled-up membrane technology also is performing largely as expected, with excellent permeabilities, chemical stability, and size-based separation efficiencies. The resulting performance data collected across a range of considered membrane configurations also greatly impacted the direction Anfiro will take its technology for early market entry.  Near-term impact will be managed more effectively by targeting a specific industry rather than the large swath enabled by the technology?s capacity for customizability.  This honed focus, together with the demonstration of a robust and scalable manufacturing process, has substantially de-risked Anfiro?s technology for commercialization, paving the way for further innovation toward addressing grander challenges such as freshwater scarcity.
